search_result.title: Vice President Kamala Harris begins campaigning with Tim Walz
search_result.text:
Vice President Kamala Harris has chosen her running mate, announcing Tuesday morning that Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz will join her on the ticket.

The decision came two weeks after President Joe Biden announced he would not seek reelection. He quickly endorsed Harris as his pick for president.

Two days after Biden's announcement, Harris visited the president's former campaign headquarters in Wilmington. They are now being used as hers.

Tuesday's decision came as Harris prepared to campaign in Philadelphia. She and Walz spoke late Tuesday afternoon at Temple University's Liacouras Center.

READ:Why Joe Biden's decision to step out of the presidential race had to happen in Delaware

Vice President Kamala Harris, Gov. Tim Walz address rally, country together for the first time

Phone service had long stopped working. The crowd stood. Noise erupted throughout the Temple University basketball arena.

Vice President Kamala Harris and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz walked out to address some 10,000 people in the first campaign rally uniting the coming Democratic ticket in Philadelphia. Harris was on a mission to introduce her newly announced running mate for the first time on a national stage.

“I set out to find a partner who can help build this brighter future,” Harris said, backed by a chorus of cheers. And, she added, “I’m here today, Pennsylvania, because I found it.”

Harris walked the packed arena through the Minnesota statesmen’s biography, from service in the Army National Guard for 24 years, to a career teaching, to even working as a football coach.

Harris touted Walz’s service as a congressman, as well as a governor, assuring the crowd he would be “ready on day one.” Some efforts she highlighted in Minnesota included protecting reproductive freedoms, as well as rights for union workers and universal free school meals in Minnesota.

“We agree on many things,” Harris said. “And one of them is that when the middle class is strong, America is strong.”

In fact, Harris called the entire election a question of “fundamental freedoms.” She stuck to these issues, as well as bringing down inflated prices, but did not dig into immigration reform. She voiced support for ensuring voting rights, gun safety and the “freedom of the woman to make decisions about her own body.”

Walz may be a hunter and Midwest gun owner, Harris said, but together, the duo plans to support greater gun safety reform.

“That’s what this election is about,” Walz said, his remarks echoing just after Harris. “What direction will this country go in?”

The pair felt their Republican challengers needed less introduction.

The vice president landed a familiar line, highlighting her experience as a prosecutor as she told the crowd: “I know Donald Trump’s type.” And Walz took shots of his own at his now-direct competition, calling Sen. JD Vance’s views harmful and “backward."

“These guys are creepy, and yes, just weird as hell,” Walz said. He added that he can’t wait to get on the debate stage.

Harris has rapidly ascended to the top of the Democratic ticket, wasting no time after President Joe Biden dropped his reelection bid on July 21. She secured the Democratic nomination last week, earning the majority of her party's delegates just one day after voting opened. Her campaign raised more than $200 million and gained some 170,000 volunteers in the same timeframe.

Leaving Philadelphia, Harris and Walz now plan to visit western Wisconsin, Detroit, Raleigh, N.C., Savannah, Ga., Phoenix and Las Vegas, according to the campaign.

“We are the underdogs in this race,” Harris said. “But we have the momentum.”

— Kelly Powers

Gov. Shapiro gets love on the Harris-Walz rally stage, after VP pass

Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro seemed moved by an electric crowd at the Liacouras Center when he walked onto the stage.

The politician closely eyed as a vice presidential pick may not have gotten the VP nod — but he got a long, loud standing ovation at the first Harris-Walz rally. At one point, he even lost his Philadelphia crowd, as they briefly chanted: “We want Shapiro.”

But he reeled it back in, correcting them to “He’s a weirdo,” as he finished his ongoing critiques of the Republican nominee for vice president, Sen. JD Vance.

“Y’all fill my heart, and I love you so much,” Shapiro said.

Shapiro looked to boost Gov. Tim Walz, while also using his time with the crowd to paint former President Donald Trump and his own running mate as threats. Shapiro touched on common Democratic themes this election season, like abortion rights, voting rights and more. He said it was the Republican presidential nominee who “ripped the decision” away from women at the fall of Roe v. Wade, while he was in office.

Shapiro called Vice President Kamala Harris a friend of two decades, as well as what he believes the country needs in just over 90 days.

“Freedom is on the ballot... But let me tell you something Philly,” Shapiro said. “Let me tell you something Pennsylvania, let me tell you something America — I am more optimistic than I have ever been before.”

— Kelly Powers

First Harris-Walz rally kicks off in Philadelphia to packed arena

Cue the mic.

“This ticket is sick,” said Jaime Harrison, as the Democratic National Committee chair kicked off the first Harris-Walz rally. He had the arena yelling as he called on the Philadelphia crowd to support Harris for president.

“Now’s the time to have her back,” Harrison said. “Because she’s always had ours.”

Speakers began to address the Liacouras Center, aiming to warm up the crowd while a line continued at the doors and around the block. They had no issue. Early speakers played up the momentum of this rapidly mobilized Democratic ticket, warned about the danger of Republican challengers, of fighting corporate "greed-flation" and more, as cheers filled the packed arena.

Speakers included U.S. Sen. John Fetterman, Sen. Bob Casey Jr. and more in rapid succession.

“I know we have some union workers in this audience,” Casey said to the rally, calling this a race for working families. (Walz is seen to bring pro-union and suburban-to-rural appeal to help Democrats clinch a 2024 win.)

One voice joined the stage as the first woman to hold her office, too.

“I need you to know this is history in the making,” said Cherelle Parker, met with applause and ovations as she took the stage.

Parker is the first woman to serve as Philadelphia’s mayor, while Harris looks to be the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to even reach a major party ticket.

“Are you ready Philadelphia and Pennsylvania, to welcome Kamala Harris?” the mayor said, as the room awaited its main act.

— Kelly Powers

Liacouras Center hits capacity ahead of Harris and Walz's arrival

Event organizers have told the crowd that the main venue is at capacity and they are opening an overflow space for folks to watch indoors. The overflow space is located next to the arena at Pearson-McGonigle Hall, also a Temple University building.

The arena holds about 10,000 people and was packed long before Harris and Walz were set to take the stage. U.S. Sen. Tom Carper and State Treasurer Colleen Davis could both be seen in attendance inside.

Rally attendees make their way toward Temple University's Liacouras Center

With an hour and 15 minutes until Harris and Walz are scheduled to speak, a steady stream of people are arriving at the Cecil B. Moore subway station, named for the former Philadelphia City Council member and civil rights activist. They're heading west toward 16th Street, where the line to enter the Liacouras Center starts, wrapping around several blocks.

Rough guesses estimate about 1,000 in line.

Traffic is stopped on Broad Street as far south as Oxford Street and north as Diamond Street. A few blocks from the Liacouras, there’s not much else going on, with a few folks selling water and T-shirts on a humid and gray Tuesday afternoon.

— Brandon Holveck

Supporters wait eagerly to attend rally

As we hit the listed kickoff time of 5:30 p.m., there are still several hundred if not thousands of folks waiting to enter the arena. The line has moved in spurts.

Kina Jackson chipped away at a lemon water ice as she walked through the line to enter the Liacouras Center Tuesday, the envy of at least one reporter.

Jackson lives in Osaka, Japan, but is visiting family in Philadelphia, the city where she was born and raised.

Jackson said the fervor behind Harris reminds her of the enthusiasm for the first run of the Obama campaign. She was happy to be around others excited about Harris’ campaign, citing how voting in the American election by mail-in ballot from overseas can feel isolating.

Jackson was initially nervous about Biden leaving the race, fearful the Democrats would pass over Harris for another candidate. She’s pleased with the choice of Walz as Harris’ running mate.

“I think it’s a nice perspective to add to the ticket,” Jackson said, adding that she enjoyed seeing videos earlier today of Walz with his family and at a state fair.

— Brandon Holveck

Attendees from near and far bring support for Harris' campaign

Tanya Lopez has been living blocks from the Liacouras Center on N. 16th Street for 13 years. She said she has never seen a crowd like the one that filled her street Tuesday afternoon – including the day when Trump held a rally here in June.

Lopez remarked at the diversity and enthusiasm of the rally-goers.

“I think it shows a lot to the world and our nation of how powerful this is,” she said.

Lopez described herself as conservative on some issues and liberal on others, but is excited about Harris’ candidacy. She believes Harris is a stronger choice than Biden to connect to younger voters.

“We live in a social media era,” she said.

Lopez added about Trump: “He’s a convicted felon. You know how many felons I know that can’t get a job.”

Others traveled further to support Harris and her VP pick. Couple Spencer Knoll and Andrew Petrick drove about two and a half hours from West Chester, New York to attend Tuesday’s rally.

Knoll wore a neon green shirt with Kamala in black text, in the style of Charli XCX’s album "Brat." Petrick’s shirt was the inverse, black with neon green.

“Biden did a great job,” Knoll said. “(Harris)’s so vibrant and happy. That’s what we need.”

— Brandon Holveck

Temple University awaits first view of next Democratic ticket

Liacouras Center is buzzing before 3 p.m.

Temple University’s 10,000-seat arena lies in wait for the first campaign rally with Harris, the assured Democratic nominee, and her newly minted running mate, Walz.

The vice presidential pick, announced just this morning, meant the Minnesota statesman beat out a familiar name here in Philadelphia: Gov. Josh Shapiro. Shapiro still plans to attend Tuesday night's rally, he said earlier in the day, as he aims to keep traveling across Pennsylvania to drum up support against Republican challengers former President Donald Trump and Sen. JD Vance.

Walz already called joining the ticket “the honor of a lifetime” in his first public comments post-selection. But in a few hours, the former teacher and outspoken Midwestern Democrat will step onto the national stage − literally.

Crowds have already started to gather outside and inside the basketball stadium, with a stream of attendees trickling past security on Temple’s main campus. It’s not clear if any guests like Megan Thee Stallion − a Grammy-winning rapper who opened the Harris rally in Atlanta last month − should be expected on stage, but remarks are eyed to begin around 5:30 p.m.

Harris' campaign has not lost any time since President Joe Biden dropped his reelection bid on July 21. Following their stop in Philadelphia, the new duo plans to visit western Wisconsin, Detroit, Raleigh, N.C., Savannah, Ga., Phoenix and Las Vegas, according to the campaign.

— Kelly Powers

Who will play Walz on SNL?

We know Maya Rudolph has been confirmed for this season of Saturday Night Live, meaning she'll again play Harris. But the question is now, who's going to play Walz?

It's hard not to look at the Minnesota governor and think Steve Martin would be the perfect doppelganger. Martin has hosted the show 16 times and made dozens of special guest appearances, too, so he's already comfortable on SNL.

MORE:Who will play Gov. Tim Walz on Saturday Night Live?

Temple University prepares for Harris, Walz rally

The line outside Temple University was buzzing early Tuesday afternoon, hours ahead of a rally held by Harris and her running mate.

By 1:30 p.m., security was streaming people inside. Harris and Walz are expected to speak about 5:30 p.m.

Shapiro, a close contender for the VP pick, is expected at the rally. He's set to speak before Harris and Walz, according to the governor's office.

When will Walz debate Vance?

The exact details of the 2024 vice-presidential debate have yet to be decided. Before Biden exited the race and Harris assumed the top spot on the Democratic ticket, the campaign had accepted an invitation from CBS News for a vice-presidential debate on either July 23 or Aug. 13.

At the time, Trump’s campaign said Vance would wait to agree to proposed dates for a debate until after Democrats finalized their ticket at the party’s national convention, which is scheduled to take place Aug. 19 to 22.

— Rachel Barber, USA Today

Biden: Harris made a 'great decision'

A little more than an hour after Harris officially announced in a fundraising text message that she had chosen Walz, Biden weighed in.

The president called Harris' choice a "a great decision." He said he's known the governor for nearly two decades, first during his time in Congress and then as a governor.

"The Harris-Walz ticket will be a powerful voice for working people and America's great middle class," Biden wrote on X. "They will be the strongest defenders of our personal freedoms and our democracy. And they will ensure that America continues to lead the world and play its role as the indispensable nation."

Biden added that every generation of Americans "faces a moment where they are asked to defend American democracy."

"That moment is now," Biden said.

Hope Walz, Gwen Walz, Gus Walz: Meet the family of Tim Walz

Walz and his wife, Gwen, share two children, Hope and Gus.

In March, Walz shared his family’s struggle to conceive and the IVF journey that brought them their daughter.

Walz and Gwen married in 1994. The two met in western Nebraska, where Gwen began her English teaching career.

Alongside her three sisters, Gwen was raised by her parents, Val and Linn, in Glencoe, Minnesota. Val and Linn were educators and small business owners.

Gwen has received degrees from Gustavus Adolphus College in St. Peter and Minnesota State University in Mankato.

READ:Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz is Harris' VP pick. Who is his family?

Walz vs. JD Vance

Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, as Harris’ pick for running mate, will now go up against Ohio Sen. JD Vance, the official Republican vice-presidential candidate. The pair are expected to face off directly in a debate, though that event has not yet been scheduled.

Walz, a former teacher, has spent almost two decades in politics as both a congressman and now governor. Vance began his political career in 2022, following fame from his best-selling book, “Hillbilly Elegy.”

READ:Tim Walz vs. JD Vance: How Kamala Harris, Donald Trump's VP picks match up

The two are opposite on a slew of issues, including abortion, climate change and immigration. But they face a similar challenge in the months leading up to Election Day of making a pitch to voters about why they're the right man for the job – and that their running mate is the right man or woman for the White House.

Vance held a campaign event in Philadelphia Tuesday afternoon.

— Savannah Kuchar, USA Today

Donald Trump reacts to Walz, says VP pick will 'unleash hell on earth'

Former President Donald on Tuesday wrote in a fundraising text to supporters that "TIM WALZ WILL UNLEASH HELL ON EARTH!"

"He's already pulling in MILLIONS to WIPE MAGA OUT," the message said.

In a statement attached to the text, Trump claimed Walz would "unleash HELL ON EARTH and open our borders to the worst criminals imaginable," as well as "rubber stamp Kamala’s GREEN NEW SCAM and light TRILLIONS of dollars on fire."

Where is Minnesota?

For those who may have failed their U.S. states exam in elementary school − or who never had to take such a test at all − Minnesota is a Midwestern state that shares a border with Canada.

The Dakotas are to its west, while Wisconsin borders it to the east. Directly south is Iowa.

While Minneapolis is the state's most populated city, Saint Paul is its capital. These two make up the metropolitan area known as the Twin Cities.

Sen. Chris Coons: Harris made a 'great choice'

Delaware Sen. Chris Coons on Tuesday called Walz a "great choice."

Coons, who serves as co-chair for Harris' presidential campaign, touted the Minnesota governor's "strong record of leadership" as a high school teacher, a National Guard, a congressman and governor.

"He will be a terrific partner for Vice President Harris on the campaign trail and in governing," Coons' statement said. "Annie and I look forward to campaigning with Tim and Gwen and to helping make sure that the Harris-Walz ticket is successful this November!”

Shapiro: Work in Pa. 'far from finished'

Pa. Gov. Josh Shapiro issued a statement Tuesday morning after news broke that Walz had been chosen as Harris' vice presidential pick.

In the statement, Shapiro said the decision was "deeply personal" for both him and Harris.

"Pennsylvanians elected me to a four-year term as their Governor, and my work here is far from finished – there is a lot more stuff I want to get done for the good people of this Commonwealth," Shapiro said.

"In just 19 months, we’ve made a meaningful, positive impact in peoples’ lives, and I’m proud of how Americans all across the country have taken notice of what we’re accomplishing here in Pennsylvania," he continued. "I’m excited to continue working to protect and advance real freedom, deliver good schools, safe communities, and economic opportunity.”

Shapiro added that Walz "is an exceptionally strong addition to the ticket," saying he will "help Kamala move our country forward."

Shapiro will be campaigning for Harris "all across" Pennsylvania, he said.

RELATED:Shapiro to campaign for Harris after Walz VP pick; says work in PA 'far from finished'

Why Tim Walz?

Walz is a pro-union Democrat who can speak to the concerns of blue-collar workers in Midwestern states.

His ability to bridge the divide between progressive policies and conservative values had resonated with his constituents, who elected him to serve six terms in Congress before he ran for Minnesota governor.

It’s also a talent the Harris campaign will seek to wield as it crisscrosses the nation in an effort to sway voters of all stripes – especially those with conservative leanings in swing states.

During his tenure, Walz sat on the House Agriculture Committee, Committee on Veterans' Affairs and the Armed Services Committee, and proved a solid supporter of key Democratic issues – voting, for example, to raise the federal minimum wage, protect abortion rights and advance the Affordable Care Act.

Tim Walz on Israel, Gaza

As speculation swirls about when Iran will attack Israel − as it vowed to do after last week's assassination of senior Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh − voters are carefully eyeing Walz' stance on the Jewish state and Gaza.

In March, he called for a ceasefire when speaking with Minnesota Public Radio, saying, "It has to be a working cease-fire."

“I've asked for these humanitarian pauses to get folks out,” he said. “I want this thing to end; I don't want a cease-fire to last for a week or something like that. We need a permanent solution.”

Following Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel, he ordered Minnesota's flags to be flown at half-staff and attended a vigil at a local synagogue.

Walz is a Lutheran.

Reproductive rights a key issue for Walz

Walz has long used his position to protect access to reproductive care in Minnesota and beyond.

After the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Minnesota became the first state to codify abortion rights via the state legislature.

The Protection of Reproductive Options Act, which Walz signed in January 2023, enshrines women’s rights to reproductive freedom without interference from politicians.

One year later, during a roundtable event with members of Planned Parenthood, Walz called Minnesota an “island of decency” that welcomes women from other states seeking abortions.

Since the bill’s passage, Minnesota has seen an influx of out-of-state patients seeking care.

During his State of the State address this year, Walz briefly disclosed his own family’s painful struggle to conceive and their use of in vitro fertilization, a procedure that has come under attack in the conservative movement to restrict reproductive freedom.

“Your personal decisions about your family are no one’s business but your own,” he said at the time. “You have my pledge as long as I am governor, IVF will continue to offer a lifeline of hope for Minnesota families.”

— Sam Woodward, USA Today

Tim Walz bio

A Midwesterner through and through, Walz was born and raised in rural Nebraska by a public school administrator and a community activist. He spent summers working on his family farm before enlisting in the Army National Guard at 17.

He spent the next quarter century serving his country while holding down a series of positions as a school teacher – first at a Native American reservation in South Dakota, then overseas in China, then back home in Nebraska and finally in Minnesota, where he and his family relocated in 1996.

Walz decided to run for office a decade later, in 2006, seeking to represent a staunchly Republican-held district in the southern part of the state.

His win against the six-term incumbent came as somewhat of a surprise to political observers, but Walz proved a popular candidate who styled himself as a plain-spoken moderate able to connect with the district’s mostly rural voters.

WHO IS TIM WALZ:Tim Walz is Kamala Harris' VP pick: Minnesota governor named running mate: Live updates

Walz holds a bachelor’s degree in social science education from Chadron State College in Nebraska and a master’s of science degree in educational leadership from Minnesota State University Mankato.

He is married to Minnesota First Lady Gwen Walz, also a former educator, and has two children, Hope and Gus.

— Sam Woodward, USA Today

Is Minnesota a swing state?

Voters in Minnesota, Walz' home state, have a history of choosing Democrats in the presidential election, and Biden carried the state in 2020.

Yet according to the Minnesota Post, many political observers consider the Midwestern state a "second tier" battleground state, meaning it's certainly not a shoe-in for either candidate.

Harris and Walz have planned a battleground states tour where they will hit seven cities in five days. As of Tuesday morning, however, Minnesota was not on that list.

The tour includes: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Eau Claire, Wisconsin; Detroit, Michigan; Durham, North Carolina; Savannah, Georgia; Phoenix, Arizona; and Las Vegas, Nevada

Pa. Gov. Josh Shapiro, Walz were finalists for VP pick, sources say

Pennsylvania Gov. John Shapiro and Walz were Harris' final two contenders for vice president, according to three sources with knowledge of the matter.

Others under consideration were: Arizona Sen. Mark Kelly, Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker and U.S. Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg.

Harris made her decision Monday, according to several media reports.

Who is Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz?

An Army National Guard veteran who worked as a high school teacher and football coach, 60-year-old Walz spent more than a decade in Congress before taking office as governor in 2019. He was reelected in 2022.

Walz has recently gained traction due to his direct and candid nature. He also may have inadvertently started the Democrats’ viral labeling of conservative opponents, particularly the Republican nominee, Donald Trump, and his running mate, Sen. JD Vance, as “weird.”

READ:Who is Tim Walz? What to know about the governor who is Harris' VP pick

USA Today contributed to this report.
